name: Refined Glassmorphism (Layered, Frosted Cards)
global_prompt: Product UI in refined glassmorphism style: dark or rich gradient backgrounds with depth, floating semi-transparent frosted-glass cards, soft blur, thin light borders, subtle shadows, neon or pastel accent lines, clean geometric sans-serif typography, rounded corners, simple line icons, strong contrast and hierarchy, used selectively for key surfaces like nav, overlays, and widgets, desktop and mobile responsive layout.

typography.family_primary: SF Pro Text, Inter, system-ui, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, sans-serif
typography.family_display: SF Pro Display, Poppins, system-ui, sans-serif

hero.style_prompt: Full-width hero with deep gradient or abstract blurred background, one or two large floating glass cards: left card with primary headline and CTA, right card with key metric or product preview. Cards stacked with varying z-depth, soft shadows, and glowing accent edges.

sections.style_prompt: Each section uses layered glass cards over a cohesive gradient or imagery backdrop. Maintain generous vertical rhythm and breathing room between card clusters. Use full-bleed background transitions between sections instead of hard borders.

button.prompt: Buttons feel like polished glass chips with subtle inner glow and soft outer shadow. Primary buttons use gradient glass fills and a pill shape; hover states brighten the gradient and lift slightly. Keep labels short and clear, rarely more than two words.

link.prompt: Links are understated but clear: desaturated primary color, no underline by default, underline and brighter color on hover, sometimes paired with a subtle arrow icon.

card.prompt: Cards are the core glass elements: translucent panels with backdrop blur, subtle inner highlight on the top edge, and soft vignette. Use them for content groupings like stats, lists, and media. Limit depth layers to avoid clutter.

navbar.prompt: Navigation bar is a translucent, pinned strip with strong backdrop blur over the page background. It uses a slim height, lightweight logo, centered or right-aligned nav links, and a single high-priority CTA button.

sidebar.prompt: Sidebars are darker, frosted columns with subtle glowing separators, used in dashboards. Active nav items sit on slightly brighter glass tiles with a thin accent line on the left.

table.prompt: Tables live on a single larger glass surface with rows subtly separated by 1px dividers and hover highlighters. Header row has a slightly more opaque background and thin bottom border glow.

form.prompt: Form fields appear as subtle frosted strips with inner shadows and thin light borders. Focus states use a bright accent ring and slightly increase opacity for clarity against the background.

badge.prompt: Badges are small translucent pills with subtle inner glow, used for statuses and tags. Use color-coded soft tones to indicate state without overwhelming the palette.

modal.prompt: Modals are central glass panels on a darker dimmed backdrop, with strong blur and a clean title bar. Actions sit side-by-side with a clear hierarchy using primary and ghost buttons.

chart.prompt: Charts appear embedded into glass panels; axes and gridlines are soft and low-contrast, with vivid accent lines or bars. Glow can be used sparingly for key series or active points.

toast.prompt: Toasts slide in from the top-right as compact glass tiles with strong backdrop blur and subtle colored accent strip on the left edge to indicate status.

iconography.prompt: Icons are sleek, outline-based or duotone, with smooth corners and consistent stroke weight. Use white or light gray as the base, with optional accent color fills for key actions or states.

motion.prompt: Motion is smooth and fluid, echoing the idea of light passing through glass. Use medium-duration (180–260ms) transitions with ease-in-out curves. Cards and buttons subtly scale and increase opacity on hover or focus; modals and menus fade-and-scale from 95% to 100%.

do: Use glass surfaces selectively for key containers like nav bars, cards, and overlays; keep some opaque surfaces for contrast.
Ensure sufficient contrast between text and background, especially when stacking multiple translucent layers.
Pair glass cards with focused lighting and accent lines to guide attention to important actions and data.
dont: Avoid making every surface translucent; this leads to visual noise and legibility issues.
Do not overuse neon or saturated accents on large areas—keep them for borders, indicators, and key CTAs.
Avoid heavy drop shadows that fight the soft, airy feel of glass surfaces.
